countries.name: Austria
countries.specialRules: In Austria you have to pre-pay taxes of differing amounts based on what kind of index fund you're in. Generally speaking you want a fund that doesn't constantly buy and sell shares like SWAP-based funds. Something like VWCE would do just fine but please get actual financial advice if you're in Austria.

countries.name: Belgium
countries.specialRules: Instead of capital gains or a wealth tax there is tax on transactions between 0.12% and 1.32%. Even brokers get confused about which ETF uses which of these two so for safety just assume 1.32% and talk to a professional.

countries.name: France
countries.specialRules: It's possible to tax your capital gains according to the normal income taxes brackets, which would be slightly more efficient in retirement.

countries.name: Germany
countries.specialRules: In germany there is "Vorabpauschale" which means they tax your investment amount every year based on how much income it would've given you if you simply did risk-free investments. For 2024 that is '2.29% * 0.7 Multiplier * 25% Tax * Your Amount'

countries.name: Italy
countries.specialRules: Theres some wealth taxes based on assets held outside of Italy, but if you simply own property in Italy and stocks through an Italian broker you should be fine.

countries.name: Netherlands
countries.specialRules: First 57,000 euros of savings are tax-free. The Netherlands is planning to move to a Capital Gains focused tax system rather than wealth-taxing investments, however wealth tax on cash savings will likely stay.

countries.name: Spain
countries.specialRules: Capital gains is progressive and goes as low as 19%. Spain also has some wealth taxes for individuals with wealth over 3 million but it's also just a massive mess of a system with local governments changing rules.
